title-group.article-title: Response of antioxidant activity and sensory quality in fresh-cut pear as affected by high O2 active packaging in comparison with low O2 packaging

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Food Nutrition and Safety, Tianjin University of Science and Technology, Ministry of Education, People’s Republic of China
2Research Food Technologist, USDA, ARS, Eastern Regional Research Center, USA

author-notes.corresp: XH Li, Key Laboratory of Food Nutrition and Safety, Tianjin University of Science and Technology, Ministry of Education, Tianjin 300457, People’s Republic of China Email: liweili1207@yahoo.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Effects of active modified atmosphere packaging (initial O2/CO2: 5/5; 30/5; and 80/0) and passive packaging [initial O2/CO2: 20.8/0 (air)] on the antioxidant capacity and sensory quality of fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pear stored at 4 °C for 12 days were investigated. Samples stored in high O2 (30% and 80%) packages had higher phenolics and anthocyanin contents compared with those in passive and low O2 packages. After 12 days of storage, phenolics and anthocyanin contents of 80% O2 samples were 2.5 and 12 times, respectively, higher than those in the passive package and 3 and 2 times higher than those in low O2 package. High O2 modified atmosphere packaging was effective in keeping free radical scavenging capacity as measured by the DPPH assay. The sensory evaluation indicated that surface color of cut fruits were stable for at least 12 days in the high O2 modified atmosphere packaging. The results suggested that high O2 modified atmosphere packaging could be used to inhibit browning and prolong the shelf life of fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears in spite of more than 50% loss in vitamin C content.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Antioxidant constituents in fresh fruits have become the research focus in the recent years due to increasing awareness of their health benefits such as prevention of cancer and cardiovascular diseases (Liu et al., 2000). In the meantime, consumption of fresh-cut fruits has increased due to demand for fresh, healthy, convenient, and additive-free prepared produce items (Rico et al., 2007). Among many fruits, peeled ready to eat pear has drawn the attention of food industry and research as a novel minimally processed product.

Pear, a good source of antioxidant compounds such as phenolic, anthocyanin, and vitamin C, is a popular and commercially important cultivar which served as the main fresh-cut fruit item. Similar to other fresh-cut produces, processing operations could cause undesirable changes in fresh color, appearance, and nutrition throughout the storage. Enzymatic browning, degradation and oxidation of pigments, water loss, whitening, and surface dehydration are likely to occur as a consequence of wounding (Rojas-Grau et al., 2009). During cutting, phenolic compounds were released from cells due to loss of compartmentalization while internal tissues expose to air (oxygen; Amiot et al., 1995). Tissue browning in sliced pear catalyzed by polyphenol oxidase (PPO) is result of the reaction of phenolic compounds with oxygen.

Abundant chemical and physical preservation techniques, including anti-browning treatment (calcium chloride, ascorbic acid), edible coating, mild heat treatment, high carbon dioxide (CO2) treatment, elevated O2 pretreatment, and modified atmosphere packaging (MAP) flushed with N2, were applied to inhibit enzymatic browning (Chung and Moon, 2009) and tissue softening after processing. CO2-enriched atmospheres (5–10%) combined with exiguous O2 (1–5%) have been proved to extend the shelf life of fresh-cut fruit by reducing respiration, ethylene production, and inhibiting fruit tissue softening (Gorny et al., 2002). Most methods for controlling cut-surface browning have focused on theoretical approaches to modulate PPO enzyme activities. However, low O2 or high CO2 atmospheres could not effectively prevent enzyme browning of fresh-cut fruits, such as apple or pear, due to their high phenolic content (Rojas-Grau et al., 2009).

Recently, the application of elevated O2 atmospheres (>70 kPa O2) has been proposed as an alternative to low O2 condition to prevent undesired anoxic respirative processes and maintain the fresh-like quality of fresh-cut fruit (Rojas-Grau et al., 2009). In previous work, high O2 atmosphere was proved to be an effective way to prevent enzymatic discoloration, inhibit anaerobic fermentation reactions, and decrease aerobic and anaerobic microbial growth (Day, 1996). Nevertheless, the effects of high O2 active packaging on antioxidant properties and related enzymatic activity of fresh-cut pears have not been demonstrated. Studies on the impact of MAP on the shelf life of fresh-cut pears have always focused on the sensory quality of the products. Research studies on the influence of packaging condition, especially high O2 packaging, on antioxidant capacities of fresh-cut pears is still limited. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of high O2 active packaging, low O2 and passively packaging on phenolic, vitamin C, antioxidant capacity, and sensory quality of fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears stored at 4 °C for 12 days.

sec.title: Fruit material preparation
sec.p: Pears (Pyrus bretschneideri Rehd cv. Yaoshan) with a pH of 4.5, soluble solids content of 15 °Brix, titratable acidity of 0.29 g citric acid/100 g were picked from a commercial orchard from Jianghua, Hunan province, China, and transported to the laboratory of Tianjin University of Science and Technology by air. The fruits were then placed in a cold room at 0 °C for 24 h for precooling.

The next day, the pears were washed with tap water and sanitized in 250 mg/L NaClO solution for 2 min at 4 °C, rinsed with tap water. Pears were peeled by a sharp stainless steel knife and the core tissue was removed. The remaining flesh was cut into eight wedges. The pear pieces were then dipped into a chemical solution (0.5% ascorbic acid, 2% CaCl2, and 0.75% cysteine) for 2 min and were drained.

sec.title: Packaging of pear slices and storage
sec.p: Pear slices (100 g) were randomly packaged in polypropylene film bags (30 × 20 cm2, 70 µm thickness). According to the supplier, film permeability to O2 and CO2 were 5.2 × 10−13 mol O2/m2 s Pa and 2.4 × 10−12 mol CO2/m2 s Pa, respectively, at 23 °C and 0% relative humidity (RH). The active modification of package atmosphere was carried out by flushing film bags with following gas mixtures (kPa O2/kPa CO2/kPa N2): T1, 5/5/90; T2, 30/5/65; and T3, 80/0/20. Then, these packaging were sealed using a digitally controlled compensated vacuum packaging machine (Model DZ400/2D, Packaging Engineering Ltd., Wenzhou, China). The samples sealed in the bag with the gas mixture of approximately 21 kPa O2/0 kPa CO2/79 kPa N2 (air) were served as control (CK). The samples were stored at 4 °C, 95% RH for 12 days. The O2 and CO2 gas compositions of the package headspace were determined using a O2/CO2 meter (Model Checkpoint, PBI-Dansensor A/S, Danish) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector.
Extraction methods for determination of total phenolic, anthocyanin content, and antioxidant activity (2, 2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH)).

Flesh tissues taken from the pear slices were immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 °C. The frozen tissues were crushed into coarse pieces, and 80 g samples were homogenized for 10 min with 500 mL of 80/20 acetone/water using a commercial blender (Black and Decker, 626 Hanover Pike Hampstead, MD, USA). The homogenate was filtered through Whatman no. 1 paper. The filtrate was recovered and the acetone was evaporated off by a rotary evaporator (Model 78820-00, Labconco, Kansas City, MO) at 45 °C. The residues were then brought to 10 mL with deionized water, divided into several aliquots, and kept frozen at −80 °C until analysis.

sec.title: Total phenolic content measurement
sec.p: The total phenolic content was measured using the Folin–Ciocalteu procedure (Antunes et al., 2010). Briefly, pear tissues (8 g) were extracted with 80 mL of 80% methanol, and centrifuged at 8000 g for 10 min at 4 °C. The supernatants (1 mL) were added with 1.5 mL of the Folin–Ciocalteu reagent. After 10 min, 10 mL of 7.5% Na2CO3 solution was added into the mixture. Then, the absorbance was measured in a spectrophotometer ((Model DU–7400 UV–vis, Beckman-Coulter, Brea, CA) at 765 nm after 90 min at room temperature in dark. The total phenolic content was determined by comparison with the absorbance of gallic acid, and total phenolic were expressed as mg/100 g of fresh fruit weight.

sec.title: The total anthocyanin concentration measurement.
sec.p: The total anthocyanin concentration of the peel extracts was determined using a modified pH differential method described previously by Wolfe et al. (2003). A spectrophotometer (Beckman-Coulter DU – 7400 UV–vis Spectrophotometer) was used to measure absorbance at 510 and 700 nm in buffers at pH 1.0 and 4.5. Absorbance readings were converted to mg cyanidin 3-glucoside, using the molar extinction coefficient of 26,900 and absorbance of A = [(A510–A700) pH 1.0 – (A510–A700) pH4.5] (Meyers et al., 2003). Total anthocyanin was expressed as cyanidin 3-glucoside on a fresh weight basis, g/kg.

sec.title: Antioxidant capacity (DPPH) measurement
sec.p: The radical scavenging activity of methanol extract of pear tissues was determined using the method of Larrauri et al. (1998). Briefly, 5 mL of 0.1 mmol/L DPPH-methanol solution was added with 10 mL of methanol extract. After the solution was incubated for 30 min at 25 °C in darkness, the decrease in the absorbance at 517 nm was measured. The control contained methanol instead of the methanol extract, while the blank contained methanol instead of DPPH solution. The inhibition of DPPH radicals by the samples was calculated according to the following formula

sec.title: Vitamin C measurement
sec.p: The vitamin C content in fresh-cut pear was determined by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC-UV) with ultraviolet detector (Odriozola-Serrano et al., 2007). The frozen flesh tissues were crushed into coarse pieces, and 10 g samples were homogenized with 100 mL of buffer (2% metaphosphoric acid containing 2 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) using a Waring commercial blender for 3 min. The slurry was centrifuged at 10,000 g for 10 min at 4 °C and was passed through a Millipore 0.45 µm membrane filter (Millex-HN Nylon, Millipore Corp., Bedford, MA) and injected into the HPLC system. The HPLC system was equipped with a Varian 325-LC UV Detector (Varian Inc. Palo Alto, CA) working at 245 nm and a reverse-phase C18 Varian HPLC column (250 × 4.6 mm2; Varian) was used. A 0.01% solution of sulfuric acid, adjusted to pH 2.6, was used as the mobile phase. The ﬂow rate was ﬁxed at 1 mL/min at room temperature. Results were expressed as vitamin C on a fresh weight basis, mg/kg.

sec.title: Color attributes measurement
sec.p: Color of fresh-cut pear was determined with a Minolta CR-400 Chroma meter (Konica Minolta Sensing, Inc., Osaka, Japan), equipped with a D65 light source and the observer at 10 and calibrated using a standard white plate.

Five fruit pieces were evaluated for each package condition. Three readings were obtained for each replicate by changing the position of the pear wedges in the optical glass cell to get uniform color measurements. Color values of CIE L* (lightness), a* (red–green), and b* (yellow–blue) were determined through reflectance values.

sec.title: Overall visual quality measurement
sec.p: The overall visual quality (OVQ) evaluation method was determined according to Aguayo et al. (2010). A group of five people was trained to recognize and score the quality attributes of 10 of pear slices in each treatment. All assessments were compared to slices freshly cut from whole air-stored pear of the same variety and purchase data. Appearance, taste, and texture were scored on a nine-point hedonic scale where 1 = complete soft to 9 = fully characteristic of fresh. A similar scale, where 1 = inedible, 3 = poor, 5 = fair (limit of marketability), 7 = good, and 9 = excellent was used for the evaluation of the overall acceptability. Only overall acceptability data are presented.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Experiments were performed in triplicate on different treatments, and each replicate had 10 bags. SPSS 13.0 software (Statistical Systems, Kaysville, UT) was used for data analysis. Data on quality parameters were analyzed by multifactor analysis of variance, and a Duncan’s multiple range test was applied to determine differences among means, with a signiﬁcance level of 0.05.

sec.title: Changes in headspace gas composition
sec.p:
A modified atmosphere was created inside film bags as a result of film’s restriction on gas diffusion and fruit’s respiration. The changes in partial pressures of O2 and CO2 in package headspace during storage of fresh-cut pears stored under different modified atmospheres are shown in Figure 1. A decline in O2 levels and a rise in the CO2 levels were observed in all samples. The O2 levels inside high O2 atmosphere (80%) packages linearly decreased during storage to approximately 55% on day 12. The O2 levels in 5% O2 + 5% CO2 fell below 1% on day 12 (Figure 1), a level that could result in anaerobic respiration. On the other hand, the CO2 levels continuously increased inside all packages exceeding 10% on day 12. The CO2 levels in the air package (passive MAP) increased more rapidly than those in other packages, reaching more than 25% on day 6 and 55% on day 12 (Figure 1(b)). Fruit respiration rate is influenced by several factors, among which temperature and oxygen partial pressure show great effects (Fonseca et al., 2002). Also, the respiratory quotient (RQ = RCO2/RO2, rates of CO2 and O2 uptakes) for aerobic respiration of fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pear in the control package with air stored at 4 °C was higher than 1.3 (Figures 1 and 2), in accordance with the usage of organic acids as major respiratory substrates (Fonseca et al., 2002). It was reported that RQ values for ‘Bartlett’ pear changed from 0.8 at the initial climacteric to 1.4 at fully ripe stage (Biale, 1950). RQ for ‘Conference’ pear slices above 1.7 after 1 day following processing (Soliva-Fortuny et al., 2007) is generally an indicative of a switch to fermentative reactions. Figure 1.
Changes of oxygen (a) and carbon dioxide (b) concentrations in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different treatments during storage at 4 °C for 12 days. (▵) CK (air, control); (⋄) T1 (5/5/90); (□) T2 (30/5/65); and (○) T3 (80/0/20). Each data point is the mean of three replications ± SE. Figure 2.
Changes of total phenolic concentrations in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different treatments during storage at 4 °C for 12 days. (▵) CK (air, control); (⋄) T1 (5/5/90); (□) T2 (30/5/65); and (○) T3 (80/0/20). Each data point is the mean of three replications ± SE.

Our results suggested that high O2 reduced respiration (CO2 production) compared to the passive MAP. High O2 could accelerate, have no effect on, or depress respiration rates, depending on the maturity and ripeness stage, storage temperature, as well as CO2 and ethylene concentrations (Kader and Ben-Yehoshua, 2000). For the reduction of respiration rate, Barker and Mapson (1955) suggested that high O2 concentration blocks the tricarboxylic acid cycle between citrate and α-ketoglutarate. Escalona et al. (2006) suggested a decrease in the respiration rates may be due to intracellular pH change and consequential changes in the enzymatic activity of the respiratory pathways.

sec.title: Total phenolic content
sec.p: The initial level of total phenolic content in untreated slices prior to storage was approximately 80 mg/100 g and high O2 active packaging tended to reduce the loss of total phenolic (Figure 2). After 6 days of storage, there was a significant decrease of the total phenolic contents in the low O2-treated fruits (51%) and the control (32%), a moderate reduction in the high O2 (80%) treated samples (12.4%).

Our results suggested that high O2 reduced the loss of phenolic compounds, which was similar to previous reports on some fruits kept under 60–100% O2 (Yang et al., 2005), but contradictable to the report by Oms-Oliu et al. (2008) who found that high O2 caused a greater degradation of the major phenolic acids of fresh-cut pears than under oxygen-restrictive surroundings. Our study also showed that the amount of total phenolic in pear slices dramatically decreased during low O2 storage, and were the lowest among the treatments, which contradicts to many earlier studies. It was also found that low O2 can restrain the biosynthesis of phenolic compounds in fresh-cut fruits, which are considered as a response to cutting injury (Artes et al., 2007). Cocci et al. (2006) observed that the fresh-cut apple slices exposed to low O2 atmospheres (5 kPa O2 + 5 kPa CO2) led to the preservation of phenolic compounds in comparison to air. Therefore, the reduction of phenolic in fresh-cut products could depend not only on the O2 and CO2 levels inside packages, but also on fruit varieties. For the ‘Yaoshan’ pear, high O2 was more effective on maintaining the phenolic concentration compared with low O2 packaging.

sec.title: Total anthocyanin content
sec.p:
The anthocyanin concentration were reduced during storage for all samples and declined with increasing browning index (data not shown). The total anthocyanin value exhibited a similar pattern of change as did the total phenolic during storage in response to high O2 atmosphere (Figure 3). While the total anthocyanin level in all samples showed a decrease during storage, the fruit stored under high O2 packaging had a higher anthocyanin content compared with other fruits. Signiﬁcantly higher levels of anthocyanin level was detected in 80% O2-packaged fruit when compared to 30% O2-treated slices on day 6 of storage. However, no signiﬁcant differences in total anthocyanin content were found between the two samples at the end of the storage. Figure 3.
Changes of total anthocyanin concentrations in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different treatments during storage at 4 °C for 12 days. (▵) CK (air, control); (⋄) T1 (5/5/90); (□) T2 (30/5/65); and (○) T3 (80/0/20). Each data point is the mean of three replications ± SE.

The inhibitory effect of high O2 on the loss of anthocyanin could be due to a lower phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL) enzyme activity (Jiang et al., 2001), which is an important enzyme in the biosynthesis of phenolic. Furthermore, Qu et al. (2006) suggested that the PAL enzyme activity was decreased associated with the increasing rate of browning index in ‘Huaizhi’ litchi fruit and the reduction in anthocyanin content in pear fruit could be a result of reduction in PAL enzyme activity. High O2 has been proved to influence changes in anthocyanin content in other fruits such as strawberries. As previously described by Perez and Sanz (2001), strawberries stored under 80 kPa O2 + 20 kPa CO2 atmosphere showed signiﬁcantly higher levels of total anthocyanin through the 4 days of storage compared to those stored in air, but remarkably lower content of total anthocyanin were detected at the latter storage period. The above results suggest that the various effects of high O2 on total anthocyanin, total phenolic, and antioxidant activity may be due to the cultivars, and O2 and CO2 levels. Further investigations on PAL enzyme activity with respect to different concentrations of O2 would help to explain the retention of anthocyanin content.

sec.title: Antioxidant activity (DPPH)
sec.p:
Antioxidant activity was measured using the free radical scavenging activity. DPPH radical scavenging activity of pear tissues tended to decrease during the storage (Figure 4). The DPPH assay of antioxidant activity of untreated pear slices on day 0 was 42.5%. Changes in antioxidant capacity were significantly affected by the storage atmosphere (p < 0.05). After 3 days of storage, DPPH decreased more markedly for pear slices packaged in air than those in MA (low O2/high CO2). Fresh-cut pears exposed to 80% O2 showed the highest DPPH radical scavenging activity after 12 days of storage, followed by fruit held in 30% O2. The amount of antioxidant capacity in pears stored in high O2 package was approximately 30%, which was nearly six times higher than the control and low O2 (5%) treated fruits after 12 days of storage. Moreover, a relatively long shelf life was found in the pear slices under the 30% O2 + 5% CO2 treatment at 4 °C, with 24% antioxidant activity after 20 days. In this study, it seemed that a correlation existed between phenolic compounds level and DPPH radical scavenging activity (Figures 2 and 4). The decrease of phenolic content resulted in a low DPPH radical scavenging activity, which, in turn, possibly accelerated oxidation of phenolic and tissue browning. Figure 4.
Changes of DPPH content in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different treatments during storage at 4 °C for 12 days. (▵) CK (air, control); (⋄) T1 (5/5/90); (□) T2 (30/5/65); and (○) T3 (80/0/20). Each data point is the mean of three replications ± SE.

The antioxidant status of the fruit could offer a valuable predictor for the overall pear slice quality. When the processing oxidative stress exceeded the natural antioxidant system’s capacity, it resulted in reactive oxygen species-induced injury and development of disorders such as browning and deterioration in sensory quality. Among the antioxidant compound, the total antioxidant capacity was the major index which has been widely applied for screening antioxidant activity in plant extracts (Benjakul et al., 2005). Martinez-Sanchez et al. (2006) have shown a substantial protection in the antioxidant capacity of wild rocket leaves stored under 10 kPa of CO2 + 5 kPa of O2 atmospheres in comparison to samples stored under atmospheric O2 levels. Our results are consistent with others obtained in ‘Flor de Invierno’ pear, Pyrus communis L. (Varela et al., 2007), and the high O2 packaging could hold the antioxidant activity by restraining the respiration as well as delaying the senecence.

sec.title: Vitamin C
sec.p:
Initial vitamin C level in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pear ranged from 4.5 to 4.8 mg/100 g (Figure 5). The vitamin C contents were significantly affected by the packaging atmospheres during storage (p < 0.05). The higher level of O2 in the package headspace, the higher the loss in vitamin C. The degradation of vitamin C could be extensively related to the O2 concentrations inside the bags (Soliva-Fortuny et al., 2002). In our study, the highest decrease in vitamin C was detected in fresh-cut pears stored at 80% O2 packaging which was consistent with previous reports (Oms-Oliu et al., 2008). In fact, fresh-cut pears stored under initial 5% O2 + 5% CO2 atmosphere preserved a relatively high vitamin C level (3.0–4.5 mg/100 g) for 12 days. Soliva-Fortuny et al. (2002) suggested that exposure to the absence of O2 conditions of fresh-cut ‘Conference’ pears could keep the vitamin C at a constant level throughout storage. We observed that low O2 (T1) packaging significantly slowed down the reduction in vitamin C levels. Low O2 atmospheres slow vitamin C loss by inhibiting its oxidation. However, some studies reported that high CO2 (beyond 5 kPa) showed negative effects on vitamin C maintenance of apple slices (Cocci et al., 2006). High CO2 could lead to vitamin C loss by accelerating ascorbate peroxidase catalyzed oxidation processes (Tudela et al., 2002). Our results showed that CO2 levels in all packages increased during storage reaching 10% or higher during later period of storage. The extremly high CO2 levels in the air package (passive MAP) is probably responsible for the loss of vitamin C in the samples. Figure 5.
Changes of vitamin C concentration in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different treatments during storage at 4 °C for 12 days. (▵) CK (air, control); (⋄) T1 (5/5/90); (□) T2 (30/5/65); and (○) T3 (80/0/20). Each data point is the mean of three replications ± SE.

sec.title: Changes in color parameters
sec.p:
Color is one of the most important visual attributes in many fresh-cut products including cut pears. Cutting, although operated under controlled conditions, usually leads to enzymatic browning (Gorny et al., 2002). Changes in color parameters L* (lightness), a* (red–green) and b* (−blue to ±yellow) of fresh-cut pears were evaluated at 4 °C throughout 12-day storage. The higher the L* value of fresh-cut pear, the brighter is the cutting surface. L* values decreased with time of storage. Obviously, after 6 days of storage, samples stored in low O2 atmospheres showed significantly lower values of L* than samples exposed to air (Table 1). However, L* values changed little in high O2 atmospheres, both in the 30% O2 and 80% O2 atmospheres, except L* values in samples stored in 30% O2 + 5% CO2 after 9-day storage were higher than those for shorter storage times. In general, both 30% and 80% O2 provided more favorable effects on inhibiting the decrease of L* at 8 days than other storage time. Table 1.
Changes of color parameters of fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different packaging treatments during storage at 4 °C
Days CK T1 T2 T3
L*
0 78.8 a 78.4 a 79.1 a 79.3 a
6 68.9 b 42.0 c 75.3 a 74.9 a
12 32.5 e 21.5 e 65.8 b 64.9 b
a*
0 −1.80 a −1.78 a −1.82 a −1.76 a
6 2.34 c 2.45 c 0.26 a 0.21 a
12 3.21 c 3.5 c 1.31 b 1.25 b
b*
0 9.6 a 9.4 a 9.5 a 9.6 a
6 12.6 b 14.9 b 10.1 a 9.9 a
12 15.6 c 18.4 c 11.3 b 10.9 a
CK: control and LSD: least significant difference.
Mean values mean of three replicates. Values within a column followed by the same letter are not significantly different (p < 0.05) according to LSD’s multiple range test.

A large and rapid increase in a* and b* values was observed in the control samples which had the highest a* and b* values after 12 days compared with that of other packaging treatments (Table 1). It was evident that a* values for samples treated by 80% O2 throughout storage was kept at low (below 0.21) and increased slowly after 6 days (Table 1). Nevertheless, the low O2-treated samples showed the fastest increase in a* values during the storage. In conclusion, high O2 active packaging greatly contributed to slower changes to red color on the fresh-cut pears. Similar to a* value, the increasing rate of b* value in samples stored in high O2 conditions was smaller than that of other packaging systems.

Color changes could be attributed to the wound-induced response resulting from peeling and slicing (Siomos et al., 2010). Results in this study showed that high oxygen, especially 80% O2 was much effective on inhibiting discoloration. Liu et al. (2010) found that the surface color of mushroom changed slightly during 10 days under 100% O2.

sec.title: OVQ of fresh-cut pears
sec.p:
OVQ was measured to decide the limit of acceptability of fresh-cut pears from the view of the consumer. Changes in sensory qualities of firmness, juiciness, taste, and visual appearance of the fresh-cut pear slices during 12 days of storage are displayed in Figure 6. After treatments, the control showed a decrease in visual appearance during storage. At the end of the storage, the control had an OVQ score of 3.8, indicating the sample was below the limit of marketability. Particularly, the OVQ score (5.5) for the sample in low O2 atmosphere was lower than those (8.2–8.6) of high O2 treatments (30% and 80%) after 12 days of storage. In addition, the low O2 MAP delayed loss of firmness and aroma compared with the control. No significant difference was detected for flavor among all the packaged fruits, though the color and visual appearance scores were higher for the high O2 slices. Moreover, there were no significant changes in the juiciness between the samples treated by 30% O2 and the ones treated by 80% O2 (data not shown). Compared with day 0, all the treatments had a decrease in sensory attributes on day 12. In conclusion, the high O2 pretreatment (T3) seemed to be most effective in maintaining sensorial properties. The results were consistent with Xiao et al. (2010) who found that pure oxygen pretreatment combined with chitosan coating and rosemary had many beneficial effects in maintaining sensory attributes of fresh-cut pears stored at 20 °C for 3 days. Liu et al. (2010) suggested that the high O2 treatment, especially 100% O2 was effective at keeping the entire quality of mushroom and was regarded as a suitable method for products storage. The application of high O2 (>70%) could overcome the defects of low O2 MAP for some ready-to-eat products such as enzymatic discoloration, anaerobic fermentation reactions, and microbial growth (Day, 2001). Figure 6.
Changes of overall visual quality (OVQ) in fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears under different treatments during storage at 4 °C for 12 days. (▵) CK (air, control); (⋄) T1 (5/5/90); (□) T2 (30/5/65); and (○) T3 (80/0/20). Each data point is the mean of three replications ± SE.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The study demonstrated that the initial concentration of atmosphere in MAP could significantly influence antioxidants and sensory quality of packaged fresh-cut ‘Yaoshan’ pears. Using of high O2 MAP helped to not only retard enzymatic browning, but also inhibit the decrease of antioxidant activity except vitamin C content. The low O2 packaging offered the best maintenance of vitamin C during the storage. The retention of phenolic contents was observed with the use of high O2 (30, 80% O2) active packaging. In addition, the high O2 active packaging could contribute to preserve the overall quality compared with low O2 and passive packaging condition. Furthermore, results showed that high O2 active MAP offers a better approach over traditional MAP in maintaining antioxidants and sensory quality of fresh-cut pears.

sec.p: Mention of trade names or commercial products in this publication is solely for the purpose of providing specific information and does not imply recommendation or endorsement by the US Department of Agriculture which is an equal opportunity provider and employer.
